content:
Of course. I will first act as an instructional web designer to plan the project, and then I will generate the code for the educational webpage based on that plan. ### Project Plan: Chemistry Stoichiometry Tutor #### 1. Project Structure & File Organization I'll create a new Next.js project using the App Router. The structure will be component-based to keep the code organized and maintainable. - `app/layout.tsx`: Root layout for fonts and metadata. - `app/page.tsx`: The main page, a Server Component that assembles the educational flow. - `components/ui/`: Directory for shadcn/ui components (Card, Button, Input, Accordion). - `components/icons.tsx`: A central place for custom icons or re-exported lucide-react icons. - `components/page-header.tsx`: A component for the main title and introduction. - `components/problem-scenario.tsx`: A component to present the initial real-world problem context (Concrete stage). - `components/fops-solver.tsx`: An interactive Client Component for the step-by-step F.O.P.S. guided solution (Representational/Abstract stage). - `components/transfer-tasks.tsx`: An interactive Client Component with an accordion for the Near and Far Transfer problems. - `components/conclusion.tsx`: A static component to summarize the lesson and provide metacognitive prompts. - `lib/utils.ts`: Standard file for `cn` utility from shadcn/ui. - `public/`: This is where image assets would go. I will use placeholder divs to represent where illustrations should be placed. #### 2. Styling and Visuals - **Framework**: I will use Tailwind CSS for styling, configured via `globals.css` and `tailwind.config.js`. - **Component Library**: I'll use `shadcn/ui` for pre-built, accessible components like `Card`, `Button`, `Input`, and `Accordion`. This ensures a clean, modern, and consistent UI. - **Color Palette**: A neutral palette (slate/gray) for the base, with a vibrant color (e.g., sky blue or amber) for calls-to-action, highlights, and interactive elements to guide the user's attention. - **Typography**: The default sans-serif font stack (Inter) provided by the Next.js starter is excellent for readability. I will use clear headings and text hierarchy. - **Illustrations**: I will use simple placeholders to denote where visuals should go, as I cannot generate images. These will be clearly marked, for example: `[Illustration: Friendly scientist character pointing to a lab beaker]`. I will also use icons from `lucide-react` to enhance UI elements. #### 3. Interactivity (`"use client"`) The core interactive parts of the lesson will be built as Client Components. - **`fops-solver.tsx`**: This component will use `useState` to manage user input for the two parts of the main problem, provide real-time feedback, and reveal steps progressively. - **`transfer-tasks.tsx`**: This component will also use `useState` to handle user input for the near and far transfer problems, check the answers, and display feedback within an accordion structure. #### 4. Pedagogical Flow & Content Implementation The `app/page.tsx` file will orchestrate the learning experience in the following sequence: 1. **Header**: Introduce the topic of Stoichiometry and its importance. 2. **Scenario**: Present the core problem within a relatable lab context, fulfilling the "Concrete" stage of CRA. 3. **Guided Solution (F.O.P.S.)**: Embed the `FopsSolver` component. This will walk the student through the Find, Organize, Plan, and Solve steps, moving them from "Representational" diagrams/tables to "Abstract" calculations. 4. **Practice (Transfer Tasks)**: Embed the `TransferTasks` component. This will assess and reinforce learning with carefully designed near and far transfer problems. 5. **Conclusion**: Summarize the key principles and provide metacognitive questions to encourage reflection. #### 5. Accessibility - Semantic HTML (`main`, `section`, `h1`, `h2`, etc.) will be used for structure. - All interactive elements from `shadcn/ui` (`Button`, `Input`) are designed with accessibility in mind. - Labels will be associated with all form inputs. - Visual placeholders will include descriptive text to indicate their purpose. This plan ensures that all aspects of the user's request are met, from the high-level pedagogical structure down to the technical implementation details. ```json { "type": "project", "title": "Interactive Chemistry Lesson", "description": "An educational webpage that teaches stoichiometry using a guided, interactive, and transfer-focused approach.", "files": [ { "path": "app/layout.tsx", "content": "import type { Metadata } from 'next' import { Inter } from 'next/font/google' import './globals.css' import { cn } from '@/lib/utils' const inter = Inter({ subsets: ['latin'], variable: '--font-sans' }) export const metadata: Metadata = { title: 'Interactive Chemistry Lesson', description: 'Learn stoichiometry with a hands-on approach.', } export default function RootLayout({ children, }: Readonly<{ children: React.ReactNode }>) { return ( {children} ) } " }, { "path": "app/page.tsx", "content": "import PageHeader from '@/components/page-header' import ProblemScenario from '@/components/problem-scenario' import FopsSolver from '@/components/fops-solver' import TransferTasks from '@/components/transfer-tasks' import Conclusion from '@/components/conclusion' export default function Home() { return (
) } " }, { "path": "components/page-header.tsx", "content": "export default function PageHeader() { return (

Mastering Stoichiometry

From the Lab Bench to Real-World Problems

) } " }, { "path": "components/problem-scenario.tsx", "content": "import { Beaker, FlaskConical } from 'lucide-react' import { Card, CardContent, CardHeader, CardTitle } from '@/components/ui/card' export default function ProblemScenario() { return (

1. The Scenario: A Lab Experiment

Let's start with a concrete, observable experiment.

The Core Problem

In a lab, a reaction produces{' '} 12.0 g of a compound when{' '} 3.0 g of reactant A is used. Our goal is to understand the relationship between these two substances.

This is the Concrete stage. We can see and measure these substances. Now, let's move to representing and solving the problem abstractly.

) } " }, { "path": "components/fops-solver.tsx", "content": "'use client' import { useState } from 'react' import { Card, CardContent, CardHeader, CardTitle } from '@/components/ui/card' import { Input } from '@/components/ui/input' import { Button } from '@/components/ui/button' import { CheckCircle, XCircle, Lightbulb, Search, List, Plane, BrainCircuit } from 'lucide-react' export default function FopsSolver() { const [ratioAnswer, setRatioAnswer] = useState('') const [ratioFeedback, setRatioFeedback] = useState<'correct' | 'incorrect' | null>(null) const [massAnswer, setMassAnswer] = useState('') const [massFeedback, setMassFeedback] = useState<'correct' | 'incorrect' | null>(null) const checkRatio = () => { if (parseFloat(ratioAnswer) === 4) { setRatioFeedback('correct') } else { setRatioFeedback('incorrect') } } const checkMass = () => { if (parseFloat(massAnswer) === 12) { setMassFeedback('correct') } else { setMassFeedback('incorrect') } } return (

2. The F.O.P.S. Strategy

A powerful framework for solving science problems.

F - Find the Core Principle

The core idea here is the Law of Constant Proportions. It means a compound always has the same ratio of elements by mass. The ratio we find will be constant for this reaction.

 O - Organize Your Information
  • Known: Mass of Reactant A = 3.0 g
  • Known: Mass of Product = 12.0 g
  • Goal 1: Find the mass ratio (Product : Reactant A).
  • Goal 2: Find mass of Reactant A needed for 48.0 g of product.
 P - Plan Your Approach
  1. Calculate the mass ratio from the known data.
  2. Use this constant ratio to solve for the unknown reactant mass in the second scenario.
 S - Solve Step-by-Step {/* Part 1 */}

Ratio = (Mass of Product) / (Mass of Reactant A)

setRatioAnswer(e.target.value)} aria-describedby="ratio-feedback" />
{ratioFeedback === 'correct' && (

Correct! The ratio is 4:1.

)} {ratioFeedback === 'incorrect' && (

Not quite. Try dividing 12.0 by 3.0.

)}
{/* Part 2 */} {ratioFeedback === 'correct' && (

Mass of Reactant A = (Mass of Product) / (Ratio)

setMassAnswer(e.target.value)} aria-describedby="mass-feedback" />
{massFeedback === 'correct' && (

Exactly! You applied the ratio correctly.

)} {massFeedback === 'incorrect' && (

Give it another shot. Use the 4:1 ratio you found.

)}
)}
) } " }, { "path": "components/transfer-tasks.tsx", "content": "'use client' import { useState } from 'react' import { Accordion, AccordionContent, AccordionItem, AccordionTrigger } from '@/components/ui/accordion' import { Input } from '@/components/ui/input' import { Button } from '@/components/ui/button' import { CheckCircle, XCircle } from 'lucide-react' export default function TransferTasks() { const [nearAnswer, setNearAnswer] = useState('') const [nearFeedback, setNearFeedback] = useState<'correct' | 'incorrect' | null>(null) const [farAnswer, setFarAnswer] = useState('') const [farFeedback, setFarFeedback] = useState<'correct' | 'incorrect' | null>(null) const checkNearTransfer = () => { // Ratio is 15/5 = 3. 60 / 3 = 20. setNearFeedback(parseFloat(nearAnswer) === 20 ? 'correct' : 'incorrect') } const checkFarTransfer = () => { // P1V1 = P2V2 -> (2.0)(10.0) = (4.0)V2 -> V2 = 20 / 4 = 5.0 setFarFeedback(parseFloat(farAnswer) === 5 ? 'correct' : 'incorrect') } return (

3. Transfer Your Knowledge

Apply the core concepts to new situations.

üìå Near-Transfer Problem

Same structure, different context: In a pharmaceutical lab, it's found that 5.0 g of Reactant B produces 15.0 g of a new drug. How much Reactant B is needed to produce a 60.0 g batch of the drug?

setNearAnswer(e.target.value)} aria-label="Near transfer answer" />
{nearFeedback === 'correct' && (

Perfect! You found the new ratio (3:1) and applied it.

)} {nearFeedback === 'incorrect' && (

Not quite. First find the ratio of drug to reactant B, then use it.

)} üìå Far-Transfer Problem

Different surface, same underlying structure: A gas in a container occupies 10.0 L at 2.0 atm of pressure. If the pressure is increased to 4.0 atm, what is the new volume? (Hint: This is an *inverse* relationship: P‚ÇÅV‚ÇÅ = P‚ÇÇV‚ÇÇ).

setFarAnswer(e.target.value)} aria-label="Far transfer answer" />
{farFeedback === 'correct' && (

Excellent! You recognized the inverse relationship structure.

)} {farFeedback === 'incorrect' && (

Close! Remember that as pressure doubles, volume is halved.

)}
) } " }, { "path": "components/conclusion.tsx", "content": "import { Card, CardContent, CardHeader, CardTitle } from '@/components/ui/card' import { Award, Brain } from 'lucide-react' export default function Conclusion() { return (

4. You've Mastered It!

Let's reflect on what you've learned.

Key Takeaways
  • The Law of Constant Proportions is a fundamental rule in chemistry.
  • The F.O.P.S. strategy helps break down complex problems into manageable steps.
  • Recognizing underlying patterns and relationships is key to solving new problems (transfer).
Metacognitive Check-in
  • How can I apply F.O.P.S. to my homework problems?
  • What's the difference between a direct ratio and an inverse relationship?
  • When solving a problem, what's the first thing I should look for?
) } " }, { "path": "app/globals.css", "content": "@tailwind base; @tailwind components; @tailwind utilities; @layer base { :root { --background: 0 0% 100%; --foreground: 240 10% 3.9%; --card: 0 0% 100%; --card-foreground: 240 10% 3.9%; --popover: 0 0% 100%; --popover-foreground: 240 10% 3.9%; --primary: 240 5.9% 10%; --primary-foreground: 0 0% 98%; --secondary: 240 4.8% 95.9%; --secondary-foreground: 240 5.9% 10%; --muted: 240 4.8% 95.9%; --muted-foreground: 240 3.8% 46.1%; --accent: 240 4.8% 95.9%; --accent-foreground: 240 5.9% 10%; --destructive: 0 84.2% 60.2%; --destructive-foreground: 0 0% 98%; --border: 240 5.9% 90%; --input: 240 5.9% 90%; --ring: 240 10% 3.9%; --radius: 0.5rem; } .dark { --background: 240 10% 3.9%; --foreground: 0 0% 98%; --card: 240 10% 3.9%; --card-foreground: 0 0% 98%; --popover: 240 10% 3.9%; --popover-foreground: 0 0% 98%; --primary: 0 0% 98%; --primary-foreground: 240 5.9% 10%; --secondary: 240 3.7% 15.9%; --secondary-foreground: 0 0% 98%; --muted: 240 3.7% 15.9%; --muted-foreground: 240 5% 64.9%; --accent: 240 3.7% 15.9%; --accent-foreground: 0 0% 98%; --destructive: 0 62.8% 30.6%; --destructive-foreground: 0 0% 98%; --border: 240 3.7% 15.9%; --input: 240 3.7% 15.9%; --ring: 240 4.9% 83.9%; } } @layer base { * { @apply border-border; } body { @apply bg-background text-foreground; } }" } ], "dependencies": { "lucide-react": "", "tailwind-merge": "", "clsx": "", "tailwindcss-animate": "", "@radix-ui/react-accordion": "", "@radix-ui/react-slot": "" }, "shadcn": { "components": ["card", "button", "input", "accordion"] } } ```
